Over-the-Air Computation Based on Balanced Number Systems for Federated Edge Learning
††thanks: Alphan Şahin is with the Electrical Engineering Department, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, USA. E-mail: asahin@mailbox.sc.edu ††thanks: This paper in part was submitted to be presented at the IEEE Global Communication Conference (GLOBECOM) 2022 - Workshop on Wireless Communications for Distributed Intelligence [1].

Alphan Şahin
Abstract

In this study, we propose a digital over-the-air computation (OAC) scheme for achieving continuous-valued (analog) aggregation for federated edge learning (FEEL). We show that the average of a set of real-valued parameters can be calculated approximately by using the average of the corresponding numerals, where the numerals are obtained based on a balanced number system. By exploiting this key property, the proposed scheme encodes the local stochastic gradients into a set of numerals. Next, it determines the positions of the activated orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) subcarriers by using the values of the numerals. To eliminate the need for precise sample-level time synchronization, channel estimation overhead, and channel inversion, the proposed scheme also uses a non-coherent receiver at the edge server (ES) and does not utilize a pre-equalization at the edge devices. We theoretically analyze the MSE performance of the proposed scheme and the convergence rate for a non-convex loss function. To improve the test accuracy of FEEL with the proposed scheme, we introduce the concept of adaptive absolute maximum (AAM). Our numerical results show that when the proposed scheme is used with AAM for FEEL, the test accuracy can reach up to 98% for heterogeneous data distribution.

Index Terms:
Balanced numerals, federated learning, non-coherent over-the-air computation, quantization.

I Introduction

OAC refers to the computation of mathematical functions by exploiting the signal-superposition property of wireless multiple-access channels [2, 3]. To improve the utilization of limited wireless resources, it was initially considered for wireless sensor networks [4]. With the same motivation, OAC has recently gained increasing attention in the literature for applications such as distributed learning or wireless control systems [5, 6, 7]. For example, FEEL, one of the promising distributed edge learning frameworks, aims to implement federated learning (FL) [8] over a wireless network. With FEEL, the task of model training is distributed across multiple EDs and the data uploading is avoided to promote user privacy [9, 6]. Instead of data samples, EDs share a large number of local stochastic gradients (or local model parameters) with an ES for aggregation, e.g., averaging. However, typical orthogonal user multiplexing methods such as orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) can be wasteful in this scenario since the ES may not be interested in the local information of the EDs but only in a function of them. Similarly, a control system that requires an input that is a function of many Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices’ readings can suffer from high latency since the available spectrum for these networks is often limited and the OAC can address the latency issues by calculating the functions, e.g., difference equations [7], over the air.

Although OAC is a promising concept to address the latency issues in the aforementioned use cases, it is challenging to realize a reliable OAC scheme under fading channels. This is because the typical equalization or phase correction methods used at the receiver for traditional multiple-access schemes, e.g., OFDMA, cannot be directly employed for OAC to compensate for the channel distortion or imperfect synchronization as the transmitted symbols are distorted by the channel before the signal superposition. To address this issue, a majority of the state-of-the-art OAC methods rely on pre-equalization techniques[10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. However, a pre-equalizer can impose stringent requirements on the underlying mechanisms such as time-frequency-phase synchronization, channel estimation, and channel prediction, which can be challenging to satisfy under non-stationary channel conditions [18, 19]. Most of the state-of-the-art OAC schemes use analog modulation schemes to achieve continuous-valued computation, e.g., [10, 20], and [21]. However, in fading channels, analog modulations can be more susceptible to noise as compared to digital schemes. Although there are digital methods, e.g., one-bit broadband digital aggregation (OBDA) [13] and -based (FSK-MV) [22], these schemes do not allow one to compute a continuous-valued function. In this paper, as opposed to earlier work, we introduce an OAC scheme for FEEL, where the local stochastic gradients are encoded into a set of numerals based on a balanced (also called signed-digit) number system [23] to achieve a continuous-valued computation over a digital scheme.111To avoid confusion, we use the terms ”numeral” and ”balanced” for ”digit” and ”signed-digit”, respectively, since the term ”digit” may specifically imply the ten symbols of the common base 10 numeral system. The proposed method does not rely on pre-equalization and the availability of channel state information (CSI) at the EDs and the ES, leading to relaxed synchronization requirements as compared to the methods relying on the availability of the CSI at the EDs.

I-A Related Work

I-A1 Over-the-air computation

In the literature, OAC schemes are particularly investigated to reduce the per-round communication latency of FEEL. In [10], broadband analog aggregation (BAA) that modulates the OFDM subcarriers with the model parameters is proposed. To overcome the impact of the multipath channel on the transmitted signals, the symbols on the OFDM subcarriers are multiplied with the inverse of the channel coefficients and the subcarriers that fade are excluded from the transmissions, known as truncated-channel inversion (TCI) in the literature. In [11], an additional time-varying precoder is applied along with TCI to facilitate the aggregation. In [12], the gradient estimates are sparsified and the sparse vectors are projected into a low-dimensional vector to reduce the bandwidth. The compressed data is transmitted with BAA. In [15], the power control and re-transmissions for BAA over static channels are investigated to obtain the optimal number of re-transmissions. In [16], instead of TCI, the parameters are multiplied with the conjugate of the channel coefficients (i.e., maximum-ratio transmission) to increase the power efficiency. In [17], the channel inversion is optimized with the consideration of sum-power constraint to avoid potential interference issues. In [13], OBDA is proposed to facilitate the implementation of FEEL for a practical wireless system. In this method, considering distributed training by MV with the sign stochastic gradient descent (signSGD) [24], the EDs transmit quadrature phase-shift keying (QPSK) symbols along with TCI, where the real and imaginary parts of the QPSK symbols are formed by using the signs of the stochastic gradients. At the ES, the signs of the real and imaginary components of the superposed received symbols on each subcarrier are calculated to obtain the MV for the sign of each gradient. The authors in [25] also consider OBDA, but the pre-equalization in this method applies only phase correction to the transmitted symbols (i.e., equal-gain transmission) by emphasizing the fact that amplitude alignment is not needed for digital OAC. The reader is referred to [26] for various combining strategies for channel-aware decision fusion under the assumption of real-valued channel coefficients.

The methods relying on channel-inversion techniques require phase synchronization for coherent superposition. However, to achieve phase synchronization, a precise sample-level time synchronization at both EDs and ES needs to be maintained, which is very challenging in practice due to the synchronization impairments and inaccurate clocks at the radios [27]. Also, residual carrier frequency causes additional phase rotations [28]. To address these issues, in the literature, several OAC methods that do not use pre-equalization are proposed at the expense of more resource consumption. For example, in [29] and [30], the authors consider blind EDs, i.e., CSI is not available at the ED. By exploiting channel hardening, the ES utilizes an estimate of the superposed CSI to achieve an analog aggregation with maximum-ratio combining (MRC). In [22, 31, 32], and [33], the OAC for FEEL is realized by exploiting non-coherent receiver techniques. Similar to OBDA [13], the schemes in these studies depend on the distributed training by MV [24]. However, instead of modulating the phase of the OFDM subcarriers based on the sign of the local stochastic gradients, the schemes use various keying approaches such as FSK, PPM, and CSK along with a non-coherent comparator to detect the MV at the ES. While they can provide robustness against time variation of the wireless channel, synchronization errors, and imperfect power control, the 1-bit quantization nature of signSGD can degrade the test accuracy in heterogeneous data distribution scenarios. In [20] and [21], Goldenbaum and Stańczak propose to calculate the energy of a sequence of superposed symbols. In [34], they show that their scheme can also work when there is no CSI at the transmitter under a scenario where the ES is equipped with multiple antennas.

I-A2 Quantization

In the literature, extensive efforts have been made to decrease the communication costs of machine learning algorithms by quantization. For example, in [35], a general quantized (QSGD) with the Elias integer encoding is investigated for encoding the gradients by relying on the fact that large gradients are often less frequent. The signSGD, proposed in [24], is an extreme case of quantization, where the signs of the gradients are considered for the training. In [36], a ternary quantization, which is a balanced number system where the base is 333, is applied to the model parameters to implement FL based on parameter averaging. In [37], by considering the trade-off between precision and energy, the quantization levels for the neural network parameters are optimized for FL. In [38], a gradient quantization method that uses the historical gradients as side information to compress the local gradients is proposed. The authors exploit the fact that gradients between adjacent rounds may have a high correlation for SGD. Nevertheless, these quantization methods consider either ideal communication channels for training or orthogonal multiple access for EDs. Also, they do not consider an OAC scheme.

I-B Contributions

The contributions of this study can be listed as follows:

Continuous-valued OAC with a digital scheme: We show that the average of a set of real-valued parameters can be calculated by using the average of the corresponding numerals in the real domain, approximately. By exploiting this key property, discussed in Section III-A, we achieve continuous-valued computation over a digital OAC scheme. With the proposed method, the EDs first encode the real-valued local stochastic gradients into the numerals for a given balanced number system. The EDs activate the dedicated time-frequency resources (i.e., OFDM subcarriers) based on the values of the numerals. The EDs simultaneously transmit their OFDM symbols and the average numerals are calculated at the ES with a non-coherent receiver. By using the average of the numerals, the ES computes an estimate of the real-valued average stochastic gradient. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that uses a general balanced number system for OAC.

Theoretical MSE analysis: We derive the classical MSE and Bayesian (BMSE) of the estimator of the average stochastic gradient for a given set of parameters such as the number of numerals, number of EDs, and number of antennas at the ES. By extending our initial work in [1], we introduce the concept of AAM, where each ED shares a single parameter with the ES to adjust the maximum quantization level to minimize the estimation error over the communication rounds of FEEL.

Theoretical convergence analysis: By using the MSE derivation and considering both homogeneous and heterogeneous data distributions in the network, we show the convergence of FEEL in the presence of the proposed scheme with and without AAM for a non-convex loss function, i.e., Theorem 1 and Theorem 2, respectively. While the proposed framework without AAM contributes to the noise ball due to the stochastic gradients, the impact is largely addressed when the proposed scheme is utilized with the AAM.

Organization: The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the notation and the preliminary discussions used in the rest of the sections are provided. In Section III, the proposed OAC scheme and its MSE performance are discussed. In Section IV, the convergence rate of the FEEL with the proposed scheme is discussed. In Section V, the numerical results are provided. We conclude the paper in Section VI.

II Preliminaries and System Model

In this section, we provide the signal and learning model that we use throughout the paper and the preliminaries related to encoding and decoding based on a balanced number system.

II-A Signal Model

We consider a wireless network with K𝐾K EDs that are connected to an ES, where each ED and the ES are equipped with a single antenna and R𝑅R antennas, respectively. We assume that the large-scale impact of the wireless channel is compensated with a power control mechanism, e.g., closed-loop power control with the physical uplink control channel (PUCCH) in Fifth Generation (5G) New Radio (NR) [39], before the training process for FEEL begins.

For the signal model, we assume that the EDs access the wireless channel on the same time-frequency resources simultaneously with S𝑆S OFDM symbols consisting of M𝑀M active subcarriers for OAC. Assuming that the cyclic prefix (CP) duration is larger than the sum of the maximum time-synchronization error and the maximum-excess delay of the channel, we express the superposed modulation symbols on R𝑅R antennas at the ES for the l𝑙lth subcarrier of the m𝑚mth OFDM symbol for the 𝓉𝓉\mathscr{t}th communication round of the training, i.e., rl,m(𝓉)∈ℂR×1superscriptsubscriptr𝑙𝑚𝓉superscriptℂ𝑅1\textbf{r}_{l,m}^{(\mathscr{t})}\in\mathbb{C}^{R\times 1} as

rm,l(𝓉)=∑k=0K−1hk,m,l(𝓉)​tk,m,l(𝓉)+nm,l(𝓉),superscriptsubscriptr𝑚𝑙𝓉superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1superscriptsubscripth𝑘𝑚𝑙𝓉superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑚𝑙𝓉superscriptsubscriptn𝑚𝑙𝓉\displaystyle\textbf{r}_{m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}=\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\textbf{h}_{k,m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}t_{k,m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}+\textbf{n}_{m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}~{}, (1)

where hk,m,l(𝓉)∼𝒞​𝒩​(0R,IR)similar-tosuperscriptsubscripth𝑘𝑚𝑙𝓉𝒞𝒩subscript0𝑅subscriptI𝑅\textbf{h}_{k,m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}\sim\mathcal{CN}({\textbf{{0}}_{R},{\textbf{{I}}_{R}}}) is a R×1𝑅1R\times 1 vector that consists of the channel coefficients between R𝑅R antennas at the ES and the k𝑘kth ED, tk,l,m(𝓉)∈ℂsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑙𝑚𝓉ℂt_{k,l,m}^{(\mathscr{t})}\in\mathbb{C} is the transmitted modulation symbol from the k𝑘kth ED, and nm,l(𝓉)∼𝒞​𝒩​(0R,σn2​IR)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptn𝑚𝑙𝓉𝒞𝒩subscript0𝑅superscriptsubscript𝜎n2subscriptI𝑅{\textbf{n}_{m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}}\sim\mathcal{CN}({\textbf{{0}}_{R},\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}{\textbf{{I}}_{R}}}) is a R×1𝑅1R\times 1 additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) vector, where σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎n2\sigma_{\rm n}^{2} is the noise variance for l∈ℤM𝑙subscriptℤ𝑀l\in\mathbb{Z}_{M} and m∈ℤS𝑚subscriptℤ𝑆m\in\mathbb{Z}_{S}. We denote the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of an ED at the ES receiver as 1/σn21superscriptsubscript𝜎n21/\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}.

In practice, the synchronization point where the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) starts to be applied to the received signal for demodulation at the ES and the time synchronization across the EDs may not be precise. To model former impairment, we assume that the synchronization point can deviate by Nerrsubscript𝑁errN_{\text{err}} samples within the CP window. For the latter impairment, the time of arrivals of the EDs’ signals at the ES location are sampled from a uniform distribution between 00 and Tsyncsubscript𝑇syncT_{\rm sync} seconds, where Tsyncsubscript𝑇syncT_{\rm sync} is equal to the reciprocal of the signal bandwidth. Note that the coarse time-synchronization can be maintained with the state-of-the-art protocols used in cellular systems. We introduce additional phase rotations to hk,m,l(𝓉)superscriptsubscripth𝑘𝑚𝑙𝓉\textbf{h}_{k,m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})} to capture the impact of the time-synchronization errors on rm,l(𝓉)superscriptsubscriptr𝑚𝑙𝓉\textbf{r}_{m,l}^{(\mathscr{t})}. We assume that the frequency synchronization is handled before the transmissions with a control mechanism as done in 3GPP Fourth Generation (4G) Long Term Evolution (LTE) and/or 5G NR with random-access channel (RACH) and/or PUCCH [39] or custom methods such as AirShare [40].

FEEL aims to realize FL over a wireless network. In this study, we consider the implementation of FL based on SGD, known as FedSGD [8], over a wireless network: The k𝑘kth ED calculates an estimate of the local gradient vector, denoted by g~k(𝓉)=[g~k,0(𝓉),…,g~k,Q−1(𝓉)]T∈ℝQsuperscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘0𝓉…superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑄1𝓉Tsuperscriptℝ𝑄\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}=[{\tilde{g}}_{k,0}^{(\mathscr{t})},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},{\tilde{g}}_{k,Q-1}^{(\mathscr{t})}]^{\rm T}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q}, as

w(𝓉+1)=w(𝓉)−η​v(𝓉).superscriptw𝓉1superscriptw𝓉𝜂superscriptv𝓉\displaystyle\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)}=\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\eta\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}~{}. (6)

With traditional orthogonal user multiplexing, the per-round communication latency for FEEL linearly increases with the number of EDs [41]. With the motivation of eliminating per-round communication latency, the main objective of this work is to calculate an estimate of v(𝓉)superscriptv𝓉\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}, denoted by v^(𝓉)≜[v^0(𝓉),…,v^Q−1(𝓉)]T≜superscript^v𝓉superscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉0…subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑄1T\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\triangleq[{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{0},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{Q-1}]^{\rm T}, through a digital OAC scheme robust against fading channels.

II-C Balanced Number Systems

We define fenc,βsubscript𝑓enc𝛽f_{\text{enc},\beta} as a function that maps v∈ℝ𝑣ℝv\in\mathbb{R} to a sequence of D𝐷D elements (i.e., D𝐷D numerals in a balanced number system) in {(xD−1,…,x1,x0)|xi∈𝕊β,β>1,i∈ℤD}conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝐷1…subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝕊𝛽formulae-sequence𝛽1𝑖subscriptℤ𝐷\{\left(x_{D-1},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},x_{1},x_{0}\right)|x_{i}\in\mathbb{S}_{\beta},\beta>1,i\in\mathbb{Z}_{D}\} as

(xD−1,…,x1,x0)=fenc,β​(v),subscript𝑥𝐷1…subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0subscript𝑓enc𝛽𝑣\displaystyle\left(x_{D-1},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},x_{1},x_{0}\right)=f_{\text{enc},\beta}(v)~{}, (7)

where β𝛽\beta is an odd positive integer (called base or scale [42]), xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is referred to as a numeral at the i𝑖ith position, and 𝕊βsubscript𝕊𝛽\mathbb{S}_{\beta} is the symbol set. Without loss of generality, we define the symbol set 𝕊βsubscript𝕊𝛽\mathbb{S}_{\beta} as

𝕊β≜{aj|aj=fbal​(j),j∈ℤβ},≜subscript𝕊𝛽conditional-setsubscript𝑎𝑗formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝑓bal𝑗𝑗subscriptℤ𝛽\displaystyle\mathbb{S}_{\beta}\triangleq\{a_{j}|a_{j}=f_{\rm bal}(j),j\in\mathbb{Z}_{\beta}\}~{}, (8)

where fbal​(j)subscript𝑓bal𝑗f_{\rm bal}(j) is defined by

fbal​(j)≜{−(j+1)/2,odd ​j,j<β−1(j+2)/2,even ​j,j<β−10,j=β−1.≜subscript𝑓bal𝑗cases𝑗12odd 𝑗𝑗𝛽1𝑗22even 𝑗𝑗𝛽10𝑗𝛽1\displaystyle f_{\rm bal}(j)\triangleq\begin{cases}-(j+1)/2,&\text{odd }j,j<\beta-1\\ (j+2)/2,&\text{even }j,j<\beta-1\\ 0,&j=\beta-1\end{cases}~{}. (9)

Based on (9), aβ−1subscript𝑎𝛽1a_{\beta-1} is a zero-valued symbol. The example symbol sets for β=5𝛽5\beta=5 and β=7𝛽7\beta=7 can obtained as 𝕊5={−1,1,−2,2,0}subscript𝕊511220\mathbb{S}_{5}=\{-1,1,-2,2,0\} and 𝕊7={−1,1,−2,2,−3,3,0}subscript𝕊71122330\mathbb{S}_{7}=\{-1,1,-2,2,-3,3,0\} , respectively. For a balanced number system, there is no dedicated symbol for sign as 𝕊βsubscript𝕊𝛽\mathbb{S}_{\beta} contains negative-valued symbols.

The numerals are obtained via fenc,β​(v)subscript𝑓enc𝛽𝑣f_{\text{enc},\beta}(v) as follows: The encoder fenc,β​(v)subscript𝑓enc𝛽𝑣f_{\text{enc},\beta}(v) first clamps v𝑣v for v′=max⁡(−vmax,min⁡(v,vmax))superscript𝑣′subscript𝑣max𝑣subscript𝑣maxv^{\prime}=\max(-v_{\rm max},\min(v,v_{\rm max})) to ensure v′∈[−vmax,vmax]superscript𝑣′subscript𝑣maxsubscript𝑣maxv^{\prime}\in[-v_{\rm max},v_{\rm max}]. It then re-scales v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} as ξvmax​v′+ξ+12𝜉subscript𝑣maxsuperscript𝑣′𝜉12\frac{\xi}{v_{\rm max}}v^{\prime}+\xi+\frac{1}{2} and maps the scaled value to an integer between 00 and 2​ξ2𝜉2\xi with a floor operation for ξ≜(βD−1)/2≜𝜉superscript𝛽𝐷12\xi\triangleq{(\beta^{D}-1)}/{2}. Afterwards, it expands the corresponding integer as

⌊ξvmax​v′+ξ+12⌋=∑i=0D−1bi​βi,𝜉subscript𝑣maxsuperscript𝑣′𝜉12superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝐷1subscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝛽𝑖\displaystyle\left\lfloor\frac{\xi}{v_{\rm max}}v^{\prime}+\xi+\frac{1}{2}\right\rfloor=\sum_{i=0}^{D-1}b_{i}\beta^{i}~{}, (10)

for bi∈ℤβsubscript𝑏𝑖subscriptℤ𝛽b_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}_{\beta}, where (bD−1,…,b0)subscript𝑏𝐷1…subscript𝑏0(b_{D-1},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},b_{0}) is the (unbalanced) base-β𝛽\beta representation of the integer. Finally, it calculates the numeral xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} as xi=bi−(β−1)/2∈𝕊βsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝛽12subscript𝕊𝛽x_{i}=b_{i}-(\beta-1)/2\in\mathbb{S}_{\beta}, ∀ifor-all𝑖\forall i.

The corresponding decoder fdec,βsubscript𝑓dec𝛽f_{\text{dec},\beta} that maps the sequence (xD−1,…,x1,x0)subscript𝑥𝐷1…subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0\left(x_{D-1},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},x_{1},x_{0}\right) to v¯∈ℝ¯𝑣ℝ\bar{v}\in\mathbb{R} can be expressed as

v¯=fdec,β​(xD−1,…,x1,x0)≜vmaxξ​∑i=0D−1xi​βi.¯𝑣subscript𝑓dec𝛽subscript𝑥𝐷1…subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥0≜subscript𝑣max𝜉superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝐷1subscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝛽𝑖\displaystyle\bar{v}=f_{\text{dec},\beta}\left(x_{D-1},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},x_{1},x_{0}\right)\triangleq\frac{v_{\rm max}}{\xi}\sum_{i=0}^{D-1}x_{i}\beta^{i}~{}. (11)
Example 2.

Consider the parameters given in Example 1. Hence, we obtain fdec,β​fenc,β​(0.28)=fdec,β​(1,−2,2)≊0.2742subscript𝑓dec𝛽subscript𝑓enc𝛽0.28subscript𝑓dec𝛽122approximately-equals-or-equals0.2742f_{\text{dec},\beta}f_{\text{enc},\beta}(0.28)=f_{\text{dec},\beta}\left(1,-2,2\right)\approxeq 0.2742, and fdec,β​fenc,β​(−0.86)=fdec,β​(−2,−1,2)≊−0.8548subscript𝑓dec𝛽subscript𝑓enc𝛽0.86subscript𝑓dec𝛽212approximately-equals-or-equals0.8548f_{\text{dec},\beta}f_{\text{enc},\beta}(-0.86)=f_{\text{dec},\beta}\left(-2,-1,2\right)\approxeq-0.8548 based on (11). The step size can also be calculated as Δ=2/(53−1)≊0.016Δ2superscript531approximately-equals-or-equals0.016\Delta=2/(5^{3}-1)\approxeq 0.016.

Note that v¯=fdec,β​fenc,β​(v)¯𝑣subscript𝑓dec𝛽subscript𝑓enc𝛽𝑣\bar{v}=f_{\text{dec},\beta}f_{\text{enc},\beta}(v) forms a mid-tread uniform quantization, i.e., zero is one of the re-construction levels. The quantization step size can also be calculated as Δ=2​vmax/(βD−1)Δ2subscript𝑣maxsuperscript𝛽𝐷1\Delta=2v_{\rm max}/(\beta^{D}-1) and the quantization error, i.e., |v−v¯|𝑣¯𝑣|{v-\bar{v}}|, decreases with increasing D𝐷D for |v|≤vmax′𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑣max′|v|\leq v_{\rm max}^{\prime} for vmax′=vmax+Δ/2superscriptsubscript𝑣max′subscript𝑣maxΔ2v_{\rm max}^{\prime}=v_{\rm max}+\Delta/2.

The operations in fenc,βsubscript𝑓enc𝛽f_{\text{enc},\beta} and fdec,βsubscript𝑓dec𝛽f_{\text{dec},\beta} and the corresponding input-output relationships are given for an arbitrary input in Figure 1. We utilize fenc,βsubscript𝑓enc𝛽f_{\text{enc},\beta} and fdec,βsubscript𝑓dec𝛽f_{\text{dec},\beta} to encode the local stochastic gradients at the EDs and obtain an estimate of the arithmetic mean of the local stochastic gradients at the ES, respectively, as discussed in Section III.

III Proposed OAC Scheme

In this section, we discuss the proposed OAC scheme relying on the representation of the gradients based on a balanced number system. We analyze its performance in terms of MSE and introduce the AAM to improve the MSE over the communication rounds of FEEL.

III-A Key Observation

Based on the discussions given in Section II-B, consider the q𝑞qth gradient at the k𝑘kth ED for the 𝓉𝓉\mathscr{t}th communication round of the FEEL, i.e., g~k,q(𝓉)superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}. Suppose that g~k,q(𝓉)superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})} is encoded into the sequence of length D𝐷D denoted by

(dk,q,D−1(𝓉),…,dk,q,1(𝓉),dk,q,0(𝓉))=fenc,β​(g~k,q(𝓉)),superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞𝐷1𝓉…superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞1𝓉superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞0𝓉subscript𝑓enc𝛽superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉\displaystyle\left(d_{{k,q},{D-1}}^{(\mathscr{t})},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},d_{{k,q},{1}}^{(\mathscr{t})},d_{{k,q},{0}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right)=f_{\text{enc},\beta}({\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})})~{}, (12)

for dk,q,i(𝓉)∈𝕊βsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉subscript𝕊𝛽d_{{k,q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\in\mathbb{S}_{\beta}. The proposed OAC scheme computes an estimate of vq(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝓉𝑞{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} by relying on the expansion in (13) and the identity given in (14), rather than averaging the continuous g~k,q(𝓉)superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})} with an analog OAC such as BAA proposed in [10] or Goldenbaum’s scheme in [20].

III-B Edge Device - Transmitter

At the 𝓉𝓉\mathscr{t}th communication round of the FEEL, the k𝑘kth ED calculates the numerals {dk,q,i(𝓉)|q∈ℤQ,i∈ℤD}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉formulae-sequence𝑞subscriptℤ𝑄𝑖subscriptℤ𝐷\{d_{{k,q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})}|q\in\mathbb{Z}_{Q},i\in\mathbb{Z}_{D}\} with (12), for a given β𝛽\beta. The main strategy exploited at the k𝑘kth ED with the proposed scheme is that β−1𝛽1\beta-1 subcarriers are dedicated for each numeral and one of them is activated based on its value. To express this encoding operation rigorously, let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} be a function that maps q∈ℤQ𝑞subscriptℤ𝑄q\in\mathbb{Z}_{Q} to a set of (β−1)​D𝛽1𝐷(\beta-1)D distinct time-frequency index pairs denoted by 𝕋q≜{(mi,ℓ,li,ℓ)|i∈ℤD,ℓ∈ℤβ−1}≜subscript𝕋𝑞conditional-setsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓformulae-sequence𝑖subscriptℤ𝐷ℓsubscriptℤ𝛽1\mathbb{T}_{q}\triangleq\{(m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell})|i\in\mathbb{Z}_{D},\ell\in\mathbb{Z}_{\beta-1}\} for mi,ℓ∈ℤSsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscriptℤ𝑆m_{i,\ell}\in\mathbb{Z}_{S} and li,ℓ∈ℤMsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓsubscriptℤ𝑀l_{i,\ell}\in\mathbb{Z}_{M}, where 𝕋q1∩𝕋q2=∅subscript𝕋subscript𝑞1subscript𝕋subscript𝑞2\mathbb{T}_{q_{1}}\cap\mathbb{T}_{q_{2}}=\emptyset if q1≠q2subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2q_{1}\neq q_{2} for q1,q2∈ℤQsubscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscriptℤ𝑄q_{1},q_{2}\in\mathbb{Z}_{Q}. The k𝑘kth ED determines the modulation symbol tk,mi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉t_{k,{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}}^{(\mathscr{t})} as

tk,mi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)=Es​sk,q,i(𝓉)×𝕀​[dk,q,i(𝓉)=aℓ],superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉subscript𝐸ssuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉𝕀delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉subscript𝑎ℓ\displaystyle t_{k,{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}=\sqrt{E_{\rm s}}s_{k,q,i}^{(\mathscr{t})}\times\mathbb{I}\left[{d_{{k,q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})}=a_{\ell}}\right]~{}, (15)

for all i∈ℤD𝑖subscriptℤ𝐷i\in\mathbb{Z}_{D} and ℓ∈ℤβ−1ℓsubscriptℤ𝛽1\ell\in\mathbb{Z}_{\beta-1}, where Essubscript𝐸sE_{\rm s} is a factor to normalize the OFDM symbol energy and sk,q,i(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉s_{k,q,i}^{(\mathscr{t})} is a randomization symbol on the unit circle for peak-to-mean envelope power ratio (PMEPR) reduction [31]. Note that we do not allocate a subcarrier for aβ−1=0subscript𝑎𝛽10a_{\beta-1}=0 as it does not contribute to the sum given in (14). Since we active only one of the β−1𝛽1\beta-1 subcarriers in our scheme, we set Essubscript𝐸sE_{\rm s} to β−1𝛽1\beta-1. After the calculation of (15) for all gradients, the k𝑘kth ED calculates the OFDM symbols and all EDs transmit them simultaneously based on the discussions in Section II. Since the proposed scheme uses (β−1)​D𝛽1𝐷(\beta-1)D subcarriers for each gradient, the maximum number of gradients that can be transmitted on each OFDM symbol can be calculated as Mpar=⌊M/((β−1)​D)⌋subscript𝑀par𝑀𝛽1𝐷M_{\rm par}=\lfloor M/((\beta-1)D)\rfloor for all EDs.

It is worth emphasizing that the function ℳℳ\mathcal{M} can be designed based on a scrambler to randomize the synthesized OFDM symbols or an encryption function to enhance the security of the OAC. We leave these extensions for future work and assume that the function ℳℳ\mathcal{M} uses (β−1)​D𝛽1𝐷(\beta-1)D adjacent subcarriers for each gradient, as illustrated in Figure 2. In addition, we do not use TCI to compensate for the multipath channel as this is beneficial to eliminate 1) the need for precise time synchronization, 2) the channel estimation overhead, 3) the information loss due to the truncation, and 4) the instantaneous power fluctuations in fading channel due to the channel inversion. Our scheme also relies on a non-coherent receiver as discussed in Section III-C.

Remark 1.

For D=1𝐷1D=1, the proposed scheme divides [−vmax,vmax]subscript𝑣maxsubscript𝑣max[-v_{\rm max},v_{\rm max}] into β−1𝛽1\beta-1 equal intervals (or equivalently [−vmax′,vmax′]superscriptsubscript𝑣max′superscriptsubscript𝑣max′[-v_{\rm max}^{\prime},v_{\rm max}^{\prime}] into β𝛽\beta intervals) and the modulation is (β−1)𝛽1(\beta-1)-ary FSK over OFDM, i.e., the scheme encodes the amplitude information into a subcarrier index via fenc,βsubscript𝑓enc𝛽f_{\text{enc},\beta}.

III-D MSE Analysis

For a given set of local stochastic gradients (i.e., given Kq,i,ℓsubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓK_{q,i,\ell}), rmi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)∼𝒞​𝒩​(0R,(Es​Kq,i,ℓ+σn2)​IR)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptrsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉𝒞𝒩subscript0𝑅subscript𝐸ssubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜎n2subscriptI𝑅\textbf{r}_{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\sim\mathcal{CN}({\textbf{{0}}_{R},{(E_{\rm s}K_{q,i,\ell}+\sigma_{\rm n}^{2})}{{\textbf{{I}}_{R}}}}) holds for Rayleigh fading channel. Since the absolute square of an element of rmi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)superscriptsubscriptrsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉\textbf{r}_{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}^{(\mathscr{t})} is an exponential distribution with the mean Es​Kq,i,ℓ+σn2subscript𝐸ssubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜎n2E_{\rm s}K_{q,i,\ell}+\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}, the distribution of ∥rmi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)∥22/Rsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptrsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉22𝑅\lVert\textbf{r}_{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}/R can be obtained as Γ​(R,R/(Es​Kq,i,ℓ+σn2))Γ𝑅𝑅subscript𝐸ssubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜎n2\Gamma({R,R/(E_{\rm s}K_{q,i,\ell}+\sigma_{\rm n}^{2})}). As a result, the mean and the variance of the estimator K^q,i,ℓsubscript^𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓ\hat{K}_{q,i,\ell} can be calculated through the properties of a gamma distribution as

𝔼​[K^q,i,ℓ]=𝔼​[∥rmi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)∥22/R]Es−σn2Es=Kq,i,ℓ,𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptrsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉22𝑅subscript𝐸ssuperscriptsubscript𝜎n2subscript𝐸ssubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓ\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\hat{K}_{q,i,\ell}\right]=\frac{{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\textbf{r}_{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}/R\right]}{E_{\rm s}}-\frac{\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}}{E_{\rm s}}=K_{q,i,\ell}~{}, (20)

and

var​(K^q,i,ℓ)=var​(∥rmi,ℓ,li,ℓ(𝓉)∥22/R)Es=1R​(Kq,i,ℓ+σn2Es)2,varsubscript^𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓvarsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptrsubscript𝑚𝑖ℓsubscript𝑙𝑖ℓ𝓉22𝑅subscript𝐸s1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜎n2subscript𝐸s2\displaystyle\textrm{var}\left(\hat{K}_{q,i,\ell}\right)=\frac{\textrm{var}\left(\lVert\textbf{r}_{m_{i,\ell},l_{i,\ell}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}/R\right)}{E_{\rm s}}=\frac{1}{R}\left(K_{q,i,\ell}+\frac{\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}}{E_{\rm s}}\right)^{2}~{}, (21)

respectively, where the expectation is calculated over the randomness of the channel and noise. Hence, K^q,i,ℓsubscript^𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓ\hat{K}_{q,i,\ell} is an unbiased estimator. Also, based on (18) and (19), both μ^q,i(𝓉)superscriptsubscript^𝜇𝑞𝑖𝓉\hat{\mu}_{{q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})} and v^q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} are unbiased estimators of μq,i(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑞𝑖𝓉\mu_{{q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})} and v¯q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞{\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}, respectively. For a given {Kq,i,ℓ|ℓ∈ℤβ−1}conditional-setsubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓℓsubscriptℤ𝛽1\{K_{q,i,\ell}|\ell\in\mathbb{Z}_{\beta-1}\}, by using (18) and (21), the variance of the estimator μ^q,i(𝓉)superscriptsubscript^𝜇𝑞𝑖𝓉\hat{\mu}_{{q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})} is obtained as

(22)

Therefore, we can calculate the variance of the estimator v^q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞{{{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}}} as

(23)

Hence, the (classical) MSE of the estimator v^q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} can be obtained as

MSE​(v^q(𝓉))=var​(v^q(𝓉))+1K2​(∑k=0K−1g~¯k,q(𝓉)−g~k,q(𝓉))2,MSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞varsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞1superscript𝐾2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1superscriptsubscript¯~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉2\displaystyle{{\text{MSE}}}\left({\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}\right)=\textrm{var}\left({{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}}\right)+\frac{1}{K^{2}}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}{\bar{\tilde{g}}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right)^{2}~{},

where the last term is the squared bias, i.e., (vq(𝓉)−v¯q(𝓉))2superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝓉𝑞subscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞2({v}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}-{\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q})^{2}, due to the quantization.

The BMSE of the estimator v^q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} can be calculated as

BMSE​(v^q(𝓉))BMSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞\displaystyle{{\text{BMSE}}}\left({\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}\right) =𝔼​[MSE​(v^q(𝓉))]absent𝔼delimited-[]MSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}\left[{{\text{MSE}}}\left({\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}\right)\right]
=𝔼v¯q(𝓉)​[(v^q(𝓉)−v¯q(𝓉))2]⏟σchannel2+𝔼vq(𝓉)​[(v¯q(𝓉)−vq(𝓉))2]⏟σquan2absentsubscript⏟subscript𝔼subscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞subscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2subscript⏟subscript𝔼subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝓉𝑞delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝓉𝑞2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2\displaystyle=\underbrace{{\mathbb{E}_{{\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}}}\left[\left({\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}-{\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}\right)^{2}\right]}_{\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}}+\underbrace{{\mathbb{E}_{{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}}}\left[({\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}-{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q})^{2}\right]}_{\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2}}

To derive the BMSE, we assume that the distribution of g~k,q(𝓉)superscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})} is 𝒰​(−vmax′,vmax′)𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑣max′superscriptsubscript𝑣max′\mathcal{U}({-v_{\rm max}^{\prime},v_{\rm max}^{\prime}}). Based on the derivation given in Appendix A, σchannel2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2} can be calculated as

σchannel2=vmax2​13​R​(1β​(1+β​σn2K​(β−1))2+βK​(β−1))​βD+1βD−1⏟Echannel.superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝑣max2subscript⏟13𝑅1𝛽superscript1𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜎n2𝐾𝛽12𝛽𝐾𝛽1superscript𝛽𝐷1superscript𝛽𝐷1subscript𝐸channel\displaystyle\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}=v_{\rm max}^{2}\underbrace{\frac{1}{3R}\left(\frac{1}{\beta}\left(1+\frac{\beta\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}}{K(\beta-1)}\right)^{2}+\frac{\beta}{K(\beta-1)}\right)\frac{\beta^{D}+1}{\beta^{D}-1}}_{E_{\rm channel}}~{}. (24)

Since dk,q,i(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑞𝑖𝓉d_{{k,q},{i}}^{(\mathscr{t})} follows a uniform distribution for g~k,q(𝓉)∼𝒰​(−vmax′,vmax′)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉𝒰superscriptsubscript𝑣max′superscriptsubscript𝑣max′{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}\sim\mathcal{U}({-v_{\rm max}^{\prime},v_{\rm max}^{\prime}}), we can obtain σquan2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2} as

σquan2=vmax2​13​K​(βD−1)2⏟Equan.superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2superscriptsubscript𝑣max2subscript⏟13𝐾superscriptsuperscript𝛽𝐷12subscript𝐸quan\displaystyle\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2}=v_{\rm max}^{2}\underbrace{\frac{1}{3K(\beta^{D}-1)^{2}}}_{E_{\rm quan}}~{}. (25)

Therefore, the BMSE can be calculated as

BMSE​(v^q(𝓉))=σchannel2+σquan2=vmax2​Etotal,BMSEsubscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2superscriptsubscript𝑣max2subscript𝐸total\displaystyle{{\text{BMSE}}}\left({\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}\right)=\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2}=v_{\rm max}^{2}E_{\rm total}~{}, (26)

where Etotalsubscript𝐸totalE_{\rm total} is Echannel+Equansubscript𝐸channelsubscript𝐸quanE_{\rm channel}+E_{\rm quan}.

In practice, the gradients often have an unknown probability distribution that changes over the communication rounds [14]. Hence, the expression in (26) has limitations due to the underlying distribution assumption. On the other hand, the analysis with a general non-stationary distribution is much more complicated because the expected value in (31) for different numerals may not be identical to each other. Nevertheless, (26) is a closed-form expression and predicts the performance of the scheme for a given configuration roughly without using sophisticated expressions, as exemplified in Section V.

Based on (26), we infer the followings: 1) The BMSE decreases with increasing β𝛽\beta as both Echannelsubscript𝐸channelE_{\rm channel} and Equansubscript𝐸quanE_{\rm quan} tend to be smaller with a larger β𝛽\beta. While increasing the number of numerals D𝐷D decreases the factor Equansubscript𝐸quanE_{\rm quan}, its impact on the factor Echannelsubscript𝐸channelE_{\rm channel} is limited as the limit of βD+1/(βD−1)superscript𝛽𝐷1superscript𝛽𝐷1{\beta^{D}+1}/({\beta^{D}-1}) is 111 as D𝐷D approaches infinity. 2) BMSE decreases with the number of antennas in cases where the impact of the quantization error on the error is small for a larger β𝛽\beta or a larger D𝐷D. 3) The impact of the quantization error on the BMSE rapidly diminishes either by increasing β𝛽\beta or D𝐷D. 4) The impact of σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎n2\sigma_{\rm n}^{2} on the BMSE decreases with the increasing number of EDs. 5) With increasing K𝐾K or βDsuperscript𝛽𝐷\beta^{D}, the BMSE asymptotically decreases to vmax2/(3​R​β)superscriptsubscript𝑣max23𝑅𝛽v_{\rm max}^{2}/(3R\beta).

As we show in Section IV and demonstrate in Section V, quantization error plays a major role in the convergence rate of the FEEL. To reduce quantization error over the communication rounds of FEEL, we introduce a simple method in the following subsection.

III-E Adaptive Absolute Maximum (AAM)

Without any adaptation, the BMSE in (26) is a constant, and the error due to the proposed scheme can dominate the estimate of vq(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝓉𝑞{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} when its value is closer to 00. This can be a non-negligible issue in practice because the gradients tend to become smaller over time. To address this issue, we exploit the fact that the gradients between adjacent communication rounds may have a high correlation [38] and propose to improve the proposed scheme with a feedback loop where all the EDs transmit only a single parameter related to their local gradients to the ES through a control channel (e.g., PUCCH in 3GPP 5G NR) and the ES sets up a new absolute maximum vmaxsubscript𝑣maxv_{\rm max} for the next communication round based on the received feedback from the EDs. The information that is transmitted from ED can be a function of the maximum absolute value of the gradients, the empirical variance, the standard deviation, or the mean of the gradients. In this study, we assume that the feedback loop realizes the AAM as

vmax(𝓉)=α×∥m(𝓉−1)∥∞,superscriptsubscript𝑣max𝓉𝛼subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptm𝓉1\displaystyle v_{\rm max}^{(\mathscr{t})}=\alpha\times\lVert\textbf{m}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{\infty}~{}, (27)

where m(𝓉)=[m0(𝓉),…,mK−1(𝓉)]superscriptm𝓉superscriptsubscript𝑚0𝓉…superscriptsubscript𝑚𝐾1𝓉\textbf{m}^{(\mathscr{t})}=[m_{0}^{(\mathscr{t})},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},m_{K-1}^{(\mathscr{t})}] is the metric vector, mk(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝓉m_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})} is the metric for the k𝑘kth ED, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, α𝛼\alpha is a positive value, and vmax(0)superscriptsubscript𝑣max0v_{\rm max}^{(0)} is the initial value for the AAM. The AAM based on (27) can be implemented in a practical network as follows: 1) The k𝑘kth ED transmits mk(𝓉)superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝓉m_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, at the 𝓉𝓉\mathscr{t}th communication round through an orthogonal channel. 2) The ES calculates (27). 3) The ES transmits vmax(𝓉+1)superscriptsubscript𝑣max𝓉1v_{\rm max}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)} to the EDs. 4) The EDs update fenc,βsubscript𝑓enc𝛽f_{\text{enc},\beta} with the new absolute maximum vmax(𝓉+1)superscriptsubscript𝑣max𝓉1v_{\rm max}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)}.

In this study, we choose mk(𝓉)=∥g~k(𝓉)∥2superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝓉subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉2m_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}=\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2} and α=5/Q𝛼5𝑄\alpha=5/\sqrt{Q}, heuristically, based on five-sigma deviation rule. The convergence rate of FEEL with and without AAM is analyzed in Section IV.

IV Convergence Analysis

For the convergence rate analysis, we consider well-known Lipschitz continuity [43] and make several assumptions on the loss function and gradient estimates, given as follows:

Definition 1.

A function f𝑓f is L𝐿L-Lipschitz over a set S𝑆S with respect to a norm ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\lVert\cdot\rVert if there exists a real constant L>0𝐿0L>0 such that ∥f​(y)−f​(x)∥≤L​∥y−x∥delimited-∥∥𝑓y𝑓x𝐿delimited-∥∥yx\lVert f(\textbf{{y}})-f(\textbf{{x}})\rVert\leq L\lVert\textbf{{y}}-\textbf{{x}}\rVert, ∀x,y∈Sfor-allxy𝑆\forall\textbf{{x}},\textbf{{y}}\in S.

Lemma 1 ([43, Lemma 1.2.3]).

For a differentiable function f:ℝQ→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑄ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{Q}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, let ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f be L𝐿L-Lipschitz on ℝQsuperscriptℝ𝑄\mathbb{R}^{Q} with respect to norm ∥⋅∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅2\lVert\cdot\rVert_{2}. Then, for any y,xyx\textbf{{y}},\textbf{{x}} from ℝQsuperscriptℝ𝑄\mathbb{R}^{Q},

|f​(y)−f​(x)−∇f​(x)T​(y−x)|≤L2​∥y−x∥22.𝑓y𝑓x∇𝑓superscriptxTyx𝐿2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥yx22\displaystyle\left|f(\textbf{{y}})-f(\textbf{{x}})-\nabla f(\textbf{{x}})^{\rm T}(\textbf{{y}}-\textbf{{x}})\right|\leq\frac{L}{2}\lVert\textbf{{y}}-\textbf{{x}}\rVert_{2}^{2}~{}. (28)
Assumption 1 (Bounded loss function).

The loss function is bounded, i.e., F​(w)≥F∗𝐹wsuperscript𝐹F(\textbf{w})\geq F^{*}, ∀wfor-allw\forall\textbf{w}.

Assumption 2 (Smooth gradients).

The gradient of the loss function, i.e., ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F, is L𝐿L-Lipschitz on ℝQsuperscriptℝ𝑄\mathbb{R}^{Q} with respect to the norm ∥⋅∥2subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅2\lVert\cdot\rVert_{2}, i.e., ∥∇F​(w′)−∇F​(w)∥2≤L​∥w′−w∥2,∀w,w′∈ℝQformulae-sequencesubscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹superscriptw′∇𝐹w2𝐿subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptw′w2for-allwsuperscriptw′superscriptℝ𝑄\lVert\nabla F(\textbf{w}^{\prime})-\nabla F(\textbf{w})\rVert_{2}\leq L\lVert\textbf{w}^{\prime}-\textbf{w}\rVert_{2},\forall\textbf{w},\textbf{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{Q}.

Assumption 1 and Assumption 2 are the standard assumptions that are often made in the literature for convergence analysis.

Assumption 3 (Unbiased average local stochastic gradients).

The average stochastic gradient vector is an unbiased estimate of the global gradient vector, i.e., 𝔼​[v(𝓉)]=g(𝓉)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptv𝓉superscriptg𝓉{\mathbb{E}}\left[\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]={\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}.

Assumption 4 (Gradient divergence).

For all w(𝓉)superscriptw𝓉{\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})}}, the second-order moments of the local stochastic gradients of the k𝑘kth ED with respected to the global gradients is bounded as 𝔼​[∥g~k(𝓉)−g(𝓉)∥22]≤δk,∀k𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉superscriptg𝓉22subscript𝛿𝑘for-all𝑘{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\delta_{k},~{}\forall k. This assumption implies that 𝔼​[∥v(𝓉)−g(𝓉)∥22]≤1K​∑k=0K−1δi𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptv𝓉superscriptg𝓉221𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑖{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{i}.

Assumption 3 and Assumption 4 do not require the local gradients to be unbiased estimates of the global gradients. Hence, they are compatible with a heterogeneous data distribution scenario where the sum of local gradients is unbiased.

Assumption 5 (Average quantization bias).

Let b(𝓉)≜v¯(𝓉)−v(𝓉)=1K​∑k=1Kg~¯k(𝓉)−g~k(𝓉)≜superscriptb𝓉superscript¯v𝓉superscriptv𝓉1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript¯~g𝓉𝑘superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉{\textbf{{b}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\triangleq{{\bar{\textbf{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\bar{\tilde{\textbf{g}}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{k}-\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})} be the quantization bias averaged across the EDs. The expected value of the average quantization bias is zero, i.e., 𝔼​[b(𝓉)]=0Q𝔼delimited-[]superscriptb𝓉subscript0𝑄{\mathbb{E}}\left[{\textbf{{b}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]=\textbf{{0}}_{Q}.

Assumption 5 gets weaker with increasing K𝐾K due to the averaging across the EDs or reducing the quantization step by increasing β𝛽\beta or D𝐷D.

Assumption 6 (MSE bound).

Let us express the aggregated gradient with OAC as v^(𝓉)=v(𝓉)+b(𝓉)+c(𝓉)superscript^v𝓉superscriptv𝓉superscriptb𝓉superscriptc𝓉\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}=\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}+{\textbf{{b}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}+{\textbf{{c}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}, where c(𝓉)superscriptc𝓉{\textbf{{c}}}^{(\mathscr{t})} is the noise due to the OAC. The average MSE due to the communication channel and the quantization is bounded by 𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)−v(𝓉)∥22]≤Q​(σchannel2+σquan2)𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉superscriptv𝓉22𝑄superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert{\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}-\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\leq Q(\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2}).

It is worth noting that the expected value of the channel noise is zero, i.e., 𝔼​[c(𝓉)]=0Q𝔼delimited-[]superscriptc𝓉subscript0𝑄{\mathbb{E}}\left[{\textbf{{c}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]=\textbf{{0}}_{Q} since v^q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript^𝑣𝓉𝑞{\hat{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q} is an unbiased estimator v¯q(𝓉)subscriptsuperscript¯𝑣𝓉𝑞{\bar{v}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{q}. The relationship between the variables and the assumptions are given in Figure 3 for clarity.

Theorem 1.

For a fixed learning rate η𝜂\eta, the convergence rate of the distributed training based on the proposed scheme in the Rayleigh channel is

𝔼​[1T​∑𝓉=0T−1∥g(𝓉)∥22]≤𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝓉0𝑇1superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22absent\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{\mathscr{t}=0}^{T-1}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]\leq 1T​η​(1−η​L2)​(F​(w(0))−F∗)1𝑇𝜂1𝜂𝐿2𝐹superscriptw0superscript𝐹\displaystyle\frac{1}{{T\eta}\left(1-\frac{\eta L}{2}\right)}\left(F(\textbf{w}^{(0)})-F^{*}\right)
+η​L21−η​L2​((σchannel2+σquan2)​Q+1K​∑k=0K−1δk),𝜂𝐿21𝜂𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2𝑄1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle+\frac{\frac{\eta L}{2}}{1-\frac{\eta L}{2}}\left((\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2})Q+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}\right)~{}, (29)

where σchannel2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2} and σquan2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2} are given in (24) and (25), respectively.

The proof is given in Appendix B.

Theorem 1 is an extension of the convergence analysis of SGD under the consideration of the proposed scheme. While the first term of the bound given in (29) becomes smaller for a larger total number of communication rounds T𝑇T, the noise ball is determined with the values of the learning rate η𝜂\eta, the noise variance due to the local stochastic gradient estimates, and the noise due to the proposed scheme. The noise ball decreases when a smaller learning rate η𝜂\eta is used at the expense of a larger T𝑇T due to the first term in (29). The proposed scheme contributes to the noise variance due to stochastic gradient calculation in (6). Hence, the standard tuning methods for SGD such as momentum can also be utilized with the proposed scheme to improve the convergence rate.

The convergence rate of the FEEL under the presence of the proposed scheme with AAM based on (27) can be expressed as follows:

Theorem 2.

For a fixed learning rate η𝜂\eta, the convergence rate of the distributed training based on the proposed scheme with AAM in the Rayleigh channel is

𝔼​[1T​∑𝓉=1T∥g(𝓉)∥22]𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝓉1𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{\mathscr{t}=1}^{T}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right] ≤1T​η​(1−η​L′2)(F(w(1))−F∗\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{{T\eta}\left(1-\frac{\eta L^{\prime}}{2}\right)}\left(F(\textbf{w}^{(1)})-F^{*}\right.
+η​L2α2EtotalK𝔼[∥g(0)∥22−∥g(T)∥22])\displaystyle\left.~{}+\frac{\eta L}{2}\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(0)}\rVert_{2}^{2}-\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(T)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]\right)
+η​L′21−η​L′2​1K​∑k=0K−1δk,𝜂superscript𝐿′21𝜂superscript𝐿′21𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle~{}~{}+\frac{\frac{\eta L^{\prime}}{2}}{1-\frac{\eta L^{\prime}}{2}}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}~{}, (30)

where L′=L​(1+α2​Etotal​K)superscript𝐿′𝐿1superscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾L^{\prime}=L(1+\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K) for Kq,i,ℓ∼ℬ​(K,1/β)similar-tosubscript𝐾𝑞𝑖ℓℬ𝐾1𝛽K_{q,i,\ell}\sim\mathcal{B}({K,1/\beta}) for all ℓ,i,qℓ𝑖𝑞\ell,i,q.

The proof is given in Appendix C.

Theorem (2) shows that the AAM eliminates the additive impact of the proposed scheme on the noise on the gradients (as in Theorem 1) at the expense of scaling up the constant L𝐿L. As compared to the case without AAM, the noisy ball is smaller with AAM. Hence, the convergence rate improves considerably, as demonstrated in Section V.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we assess the proposed scheme numerically for D∈{1,2}𝐷12D\in\{1,2\} and β∈{3,5,7}𝛽357\beta\in\{3,5,7\}. We demonstrate its BMSE performance and the test accuracy results based on FEEL under homogeneous and heterogeneous data distributions. For the comparisons, we consider Goldenbaum’s scheme (without channel inversion) [20, 34] and FSK-MV [31, 22] since they rely on non-coherent techniques, similar to the proposed scheme. We also provide the results without OAC based on SGD. We do not consider methods based on channel inversion techniques as their performance can deteriorate quickly in the presence of synchronization errors [32, 31].

Goldenbaum’s scheme aims to compute continuous-valued functions based on analog modulation. After the symbol at the k𝑘kth ED is processed with a function ϵ​(x)=a​x+bitalic-ϵ𝑥𝑎𝑥𝑏\epsilon(x)=ax+b that results in a non-negative value for a=1/vmax𝑎1subscript𝑣maxa=1/v_{\rm max} and b=vmax𝑏subscript𝑣maxb=v_{\rm max}, the square root of the resulting value is multiplied with a unimodular sequence of length L𝐿L as ϵ​(g~k,q(𝓉))×[ej​θk,1,…,ej​θk,L]italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉superscriptejsubscript𝜃𝑘1…superscriptejsubscript𝜃𝑘𝐿\sqrt{\epsilon({\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})})}\times[{{\rm e}^{{\rm j}\theta_{k,1}}},\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},{{\rm e}^{{\rm j}\theta_{k,L}}}]. At the receiver, an estimate of the aggregated symbol is obtained after processing the average energy of the received sequence across R𝑅R antennas with another affine function δ​(x)=(x−K​b)/a𝛿𝑥𝑥𝐾𝑏𝑎\delta(x)=(x-Kb)/a to reverse the impact of ϵ​(x)italic-ϵ𝑥\epsilon(x) on the superposed symbols. The main shortcoming of this scheme is that it causes additional interference terms for L<K𝐿𝐾L<K. For the numerical analysis, we consider L∈{4,12}𝐿412L\in\{4,12\} and choose the sequence elements from {1,−1,j,−j}11jj\{1,-1,{\rm j},-{\rm j}\} randomly. The EDs transmit the sequences by mapping them to the OFDM subcarriers.

FSK-MV relies on digital modulation to represent two discrete states, i.e., {−1,1}11\{-1,1\}, and targets to compute a specific function, i.e., MV, for distributed training by MV. With this method, even if the value of the symbol is very close to 00, the transmitted values are 111 and −11-1. Hence, without any precaution, it can bias the training for the scenarios with heterogeneous data distribution.

For all simulations, we consider a single cell with K=25𝐾25K=25 EDs. We set the SNR, i.e., 1/σn21superscriptsubscript𝜎n21/\sigma_{\rm n}^{2}, to be 202020 dB, and choose the number of antennas at the ES as R∈{1,25}𝑅125R\in\{1,25\}.

V-A BMSE and error distribution

In this subsection, we analyze the BMSE of the estimator of (19). We calculate the BMSE through simulations for g~k,q(𝓉)∼𝒰​(−1,1)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉𝒰11{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}\sim\mathcal{U}({-1,1}) and g~k,q(𝓉)∼𝒩​(0,0.2)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑘𝑞𝓉𝒩00.2{\tilde{g}}_{k,q}^{(\mathscr{t})}\sim\mathcal{N}({0,0.2}), ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k. For the proposed scheme, we set vmaxsubscript𝑣maxv_{\rm max} to (βD−1)/βDsuperscript𝛽𝐷1superscript𝛽𝐷(\beta^{D}-1)/\beta^{D} by taking the quantization step into account. For Goldenbaum’s scheme, we clamp the outcome if it is not within the range [1,1]11[1,1] and set vmaxsubscript𝑣maxv_{\rm max} to 111.

In Figure 4LABEL:sub@subfig:mse_uni and Figure 4LABEL:sub@subfig:mse_gau, we plot the BMSE versus the number of antennas for the uniform and Gaussian distributions, respectively. As can be seen from Figure 4LABEL:sub@subfig:mse_uni, the simulation results exactly match the theoretical results based on (26). The results are also aligned with the discussions provided in Section III-D. Increasing β𝛽\beta reduces the BMSE. While a larger D𝐷D decreases the BMSE (by reducing the quantization error), its impact on the BMSE quickly saturates. Similarly, Goldenbaum’s scheme performance improves by increasing the number of antennas. However, its performance is slightly worse than the proposed scheme for the same amount of resource consumption. Similar observations can also be made from Figure 4LABEL:sub@subfig:mse_gau although the distribution is different from the uniform distribution. We also observe that the theoretical BMSE results are more pessimistic than the ones in this scenario. For example, the BMSE results for the uniform and Gaussian distribution for a single antenna are around 0.10.10.1 and 0.070.070.07, respectively.

In Figure 5, we plot the histogram of the error for the uniform distribution. The main observation is that the error distribution for Goldenbaum’s scheme is skewed for R=1𝑅1R=1 antenna, while it is symmetric for the proposed scheme. For R=25𝑅25R=25 antennas, Goldenbaum’s scheme becomes less skewed due to the channel hardening.

V-B FEEL

To numerically analyze OAC with the proposed scheme for FEEL, we consider the learning task of handwritten-digit recognition. For the fading channel, we consider ITU Extended Pedestrian A (EPA) with no mobility and regenerate the channels between the ES and the EDs independently for each communication round to capture the long-term channel variations. The subcarrier spacing is set to 151515 kHz. We use M=1200𝑀1200M=1200 subcarriers (i.e., the signal bandwidth is 181818 MHz). Hence, the difference between the time of arrival of the ED signals is maximum Tsync=55.6subscript𝑇sync55.6T_{\rm sync}=55.6 ns. We assume that the synchronization uncertainty at the ES is Nerr=3subscript𝑁err3N_{\text{err}}=3 samples.

For the local data at the EDs, we use the MNIST database that contains labeled handwritten-digit images size of 28×28282828\times 28 from digit 0 to digit 9. We distribute the data samples in the MNIST database to the EDs to generate representative results for FEEL. We consider both homogeneous and heterogeneous data distributions in the cell. To prepare the data, we first choose |𝒟|=25000𝒟25000|\mathcal{D}|=25000 training images from the database, where each digit has distinct 250025002500 images. For the scenario with the homogeneous data distribution, we assume that each ED has 250250250 distinct images for each digit. As done in [31], for the scenario with the heterogeneous data distribution, we divide the cell into 5 areas with concentric circles and the EDs located in u𝑢uth area have the data samples with the labels {u−1,u,1+u,2+u,3+u,4+u}𝑢1𝑢1𝑢2𝑢3𝑢4𝑢\{u-1,u,1+u,2+u,3+u,4+u\} for u∈{1,…,5}𝑢1…5u\in\{1,\hbox to10.00002pt{.\hss.\hss.},5\} (See [31, Figure 3] for an illustration). The number of EDs in each area is 555. As discussed in Section II, we assume that the path loss is compensated through a power control mechanism. For the model, we consider a convolution neural network (CNN) given in [22, Table I]. At the input layer, standard normalization is applied to the data. Our model has Q=123090𝑄123090Q=123090 learnable parameters. For the update rule, the learning rate is set to 0.0010.0010.001. The batch size nbsubscript𝑛bn_{\rm b} is set to 646464. To demonstrate the compatibility of the proposed scheme to SGD with momentum, we also provide the test accuracy results when the momentum is 0.90.90.9. For the test accuracy calculations, we use 100001000010000 test samples available in the MNIST database.

In Figure 6, we provide the test accuracy versus communication rounds for the scenario with homogeneous data distribution for R=1𝑅1R=1 antenna. In Figure 6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_woM_woAAM, the momentum is zero and we do not consider the AAM and set vmax=1subscript𝑣max1v_{\rm max}=1. For this scenario, the accuracy results improve with the proposed scheme for larger β𝛽\beta or D𝐷D (i.e., less σchannel2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}). The proposed scheme without AAM becomes more blind to the gradients over the communication rounds as their magnitudes tend to reduce. The FSK-MV is superior to the proposed scheme because FSK-MV is based on signSGD, while the proposed scheme implements SGD and the proposed scheme increases the noise on the gradient estimates as predicted by Theorem 1. In [24], it was also mentioned that signSGD can outperform SGD by providing stronger weight to the gradient direction as compared to SGD when the gradients are noisy. Goldenbaum’s scheme performs similarly to the proposed scheme for large β𝛽\beta and D𝐷D. However, since it is based on analog modulation, it is much more robust to quantization errors as compared to the proposed scheme without AAM. In Figure 6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_woM_wAAM, we re-run the simulation with AAM. In this case, the convergence rate improves considerably for all β𝛽\beta and D𝐷D since AAM eliminates the additive noise term due to the proposed scheme in Theorem 1. The performance with the choice of {β=3,D=1}formulae-sequence𝛽3𝐷1\{\beta=3,D=1\} is worse than the other configurations since the quantization error is dominant in the case. The best performance is obtained with the FSK-MV due to its inherent benefits of signSGD. In Figure 6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_wM_w0AAM, SGD is used with the momentum. A non-zero momentum improves the convergence rates for all configurations. However, it causes an unstable behavior for Goldenbaum’s scheme, which may be due to the skewed error distribution shown in Figure 5. In Figure 6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_wM_wAAM, we re-evaluate the same configurations with the AAM. In this case, both test accuracy and the convergence rate are improved for the proposed scheme. Also, the final test accuracy reaches almost 98%, better than the one with FSK-MV. Similarly, AAM also improves Goldenbaum’s scheme while addressing the instability.

In Figure 7, we consider R=25𝑅25R=25 antennas. Although using more antennas can improve the BMSE considerably, its impact on the test accuracy for the proposed scheme is almost negligible. This is because using more antennas reduces the channel noise as in Figure 4, but it cannot reduce the quantization noise which is a function of vmaxsubscript𝑣maxv_{\rm max} and the gradient distribution changing over communication rounds. The results in Figure 7 indicate that the proposed scheme can achieve notable test accuracy results if the quantization error is reduced at the expense of more resource consumption even when there is only a single antenna at the ES. As can be seen from Figure 7LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R25_woM_wAAM, the instability of the Goldenbaum’s scheme in Figure 6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_woM_wAAM is addressed with more antennas.

In Figure 8, the test accuracy is evaluated when the data distribution is highly heterogeneous, i.e., each ED has only 6 unique digits. In this case, the performance of the FSK-MV degrades drastically, whereas the performance of the proposed scheme is similar to the one in Figure 6. The test accuracy under heterogeneous data distribution is less than 80% for the FSK-MV (this is also reported in [31]). This is because of the bias in the MV for the heterogeneous data distribution scenario. For example, the digits 0 and 9 are available at fewer EDs, which makes the MV biased. Hence, the training does not learn these digits well. On the other hand, the proposed scheme with large β𝛽\beta and D𝐷D can achieve more than 90% test accuracy as shown in Figure 8 for R=1𝑅1R=1. A similar observation can be made for R=25𝑅25R=25 as in Figure 9LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_heto_R25_woM_woAAM-LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_heto_R25_wM_wAAM, i.e., the proposed scheme can provide test accuracy up to 98% even if the data distribution is not homogeneous.

In Figure 10, we provide the simulation results for CIFAR10 (|𝒟|=50000𝒟50000|\mathcal{D}|=50000). For CIFAR10, the neural network in [22, Table I] is extended to three channels, where the size of each channel is 32 by 32. It is well-known that CIFAR10 is a more challenging dataset than MNIST and the test accuracy is less than 70 percent. However, the relative orders of the curves for the proposed scheme are consistent with ones in Figure6LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_homo_R1_woM_wAAM and Figure8LABEL:sub@subfig:acc_heto_R1_woM_wAAM)

VI Concluding Remarks

In this study, we investigate an OAC method that exploits balanced number systems for gradient aggregation. The proposed scheme achieves a continuous-valued computation through a digital scheme by exploiting the fact that the average of the numerals in the real domain can be used to compute the average of the corresponding real-valued parameters approximately. With the proposed OAC method, the local stochastic gradients are encoded into a sequence where the elements of the sequence determine the activated OFDM subcarriers. We also use a non-coherent receiver to eliminate the precise sample-level time synchronization, channel estimation overhead, and power instabilities due to the channel inversion techniques. To improve its MSE performance, we also introduce AAM. We theoretically analyze its MSE performance and its convergence rate for FEEL by considering both homogeneous and heterogeneous distributions. Our numerical results demonstrate that the test accuracy of the FEEL with the proposed scheme using AAM can reach up to 98% even when the EDs do not have all labels in their data sets.

The proposed scheme provides a potentially rich area to be investigated. For example, in this study, we consider gradient aggregation. On the other hand, one open question is whether the proposed scheme can also be utilized for parameter aggregation. Based on our numerical tests, the performance (e.g., test accuracy) can be poor as the neural network may not be tolerant to the errors in the model parameters due to the proposed scheme. Hence, evaluating (and enhancing) the proposed scheme with a noise-tolerant neural network (e.g., quantized neural networks) along with various datasets is an interesting future research direction that can be pursued.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 1

Proof.

By Assumption 2, we utilize Lemma 1 to obtain the following inequality:

F​(w(𝓉+1))𝐹superscriptw𝓉1\displaystyle F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)}) −F​(w(𝓉))≤−η​g(𝓉)T​v^(𝓉)+η2​L2​∥v^(𝓉)∥22,𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝜂superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉Tsuperscript^v𝓉superscript𝜂2𝐿2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉22\displaystyle-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})\leq-\eta{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}~{},

for w(𝓉+1)=w(𝓉)−η​v^(𝓉)superscriptw𝓉1superscriptw𝓉𝜂superscript^v𝓉\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)}=\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\eta\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}. By using Assumptions 3 and Assumption 5, we obtain

𝔼​[g(𝓉)T​v^(𝓉)]=g(𝓉)T​(𝔼​[v(𝓉)+b(𝓉)+c(𝓉)])=∥g(𝓉)∥22.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉Tsuperscript^v𝓉superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉T𝔼delimited-[]superscriptv𝓉superscriptb𝓉superscriptc𝓉superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]={{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}\left({\mathbb{E}}\left[\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}+{\textbf{{b}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}+{\textbf{{c}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]\right)=\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}~{}.

By using Assumptions 4-6, we can also obtain

𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)∥22]=∥𝔼​[v^(𝓉)]∥22+𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)−𝔼​[v^(𝓉)]∥22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉22superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript^v𝓉22𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉𝔼delimited-[]superscript^v𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]=\left\lVert{\mathbb{E}}\left[\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]\right\rVert_{2}^{2}+{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\mathbb{E}}\left[\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
=∥g(𝓉)∥22+𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)−v(𝓉)∥22]⏟≤(σchannel2+σquan2)​Q+𝔼​[∥v(𝓉)−g(𝓉)∥22]⏟≤1K​∑k=0K−1δi.absentsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉superscriptv𝓉22absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2𝑄subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptv𝓉superscriptg𝓉22absent1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle=\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}+\underbrace{{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]}_{\leq(\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2})Q}+\underbrace{{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]}_{\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{i}}~{}. (32)

Therefore, for a given w(𝓉)superscriptw𝓉\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})}, the expected improvement can be expressed as

𝔼​[F​(w(𝓉+1))−F​(w(𝓉))]=−η​g(𝓉)T​𝔼​[v^(𝓉)]+η2​L2​𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)∥22]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptw𝓉1𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝜂superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉T𝔼delimited-[]superscript^v𝓉superscript𝜂2𝐿2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)})-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})\right]=-\eta{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]~{}
≤−η​∥g(𝓉)∥22+η2​L2​(∥g(𝓉)∥22+(σchannel2+σquan2)​Q+1K​∑k=0K−1δk).absent𝜂superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22superscript𝜂2𝐿2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2𝑄1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\eta\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}\left(\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}+(\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2})Q+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}\right).

By using Assumption 1, we perform a telescoping sum over the iterations and calculate the expectation over the randomness in the trajectory as

F​(w(0))−F∗𝐹superscriptw0superscript𝐹\displaystyle F(\textbf{w}^{(0)})-F^{*} ≥F​(w(0))−𝔼​[F​(w(T))]absent𝐹superscriptw0𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptw𝑇\displaystyle\geq F(\textbf{w}^{(0)})-{\mathbb{E}}\left[F(\textbf{w}^{(T)})\right]
=𝔼​[∑𝓉=0T−1F​(w(𝓉))−F​(w(𝓉+1))]absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉0𝑇1𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝐹superscriptw𝓉1\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=0}^{T-1}F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)})\right]
≥∑𝓉=0T−1𝔼​[F​(w(𝓉))−F​(w(𝓉+1))]absentsuperscriptsubscript𝓉0𝑇1𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝐹superscriptw𝓉1\displaystyle\geq\sum_{\mathscr{t}=0}^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\left[F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)})\right]
≥(−η+η2​L2)​𝔼​[∑𝓉=0T−1∥g(𝓉)∥22]absent𝜂superscript𝜂2𝐿2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉0𝑇1superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22\displaystyle\geq(-\eta+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}){\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=0}^{T-1}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
+η2​L​T2​((σchannel2+σquan2)​Q+1K​∑k=0K−1δk).superscript𝜂2𝐿𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝜎channel2superscriptsubscript𝜎quan2𝑄1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}+\frac{\eta^{2}LT}{2}\left((\sigma_{\rm channel}^{2}+\sigma_{\rm quan}^{2})Q+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}\right)~{}.

By rearranging the terms, (29) is reached. ∎

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2

Proof.

The proof of Theorem 2 is similar to that of Theorem 1. We re-evaluate 𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)−v(𝓉)∥22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉superscriptv𝓉22{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right] in (32) under AAM. To this end, let ak(𝓉)≜𝔼​[g~k(𝓉)−g(𝓉)]≜subscriptsuperscripta𝓉𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉superscriptg𝓉{\textbf{{a}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{k}\triangleq{\mathbb{E}}\left[\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right] be the bias vector due to data heterogeneity. Based on Assumption 4,

𝔼​[∥g~k(𝓉)∥22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right] =𝔼​[∥g~k(𝓉)−g(𝓉)∥22]−∥g(𝓉)∥22−2​g(𝓉)T​ak(𝓉)absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉superscriptg𝓉22superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉222superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉Tsubscriptsuperscripta𝓉𝑘\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t})}-{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]-\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}-2{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}{\textbf{{a}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{k}
≤δk+∥g(𝓉)∥22+2​g(𝓉)T​ak(𝓉).absentsubscript𝛿𝑘superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉222superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉Tsubscriptsuperscripta𝓉𝑘\displaystyle\leq\delta_{k}+\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}+2{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}{\textbf{{a}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}_{k}~{}. (33)

Therefore, based on (27), (33), and by Assumption 3,

𝔼v^(𝓉)​[∥v^(𝓉)−v(𝓉)∥22]=Etotal​𝔼{g~k(𝓉−1)}​[vmax(𝓉)2]subscript𝔼superscript^v𝓉delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉superscriptv𝓉22subscript𝐸totalsubscript𝔼superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉1delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣max𝓉2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}_{\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}-\textbf{v}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]=E_{\rm total}{\mathbb{E}_{\{\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\}}}\left[{v_{\rm max}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{2}\right]
=α2​Etotal​𝔼{g~k(𝓉−1)}​[∥m(𝓉−1)∥∞2]absentsuperscript𝛼2subscript𝐸totalsubscript𝔼superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉1delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptm𝓉12\displaystyle=\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}{\mathbb{E}_{\{\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\}}}\left[\lVert\textbf{m}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{\infty}^{2}\right]
≤α2​Etotal​𝔼{g~k(𝓉−1)}​[∥m(𝓉−1)∥22]absentsuperscript𝛼2subscript𝐸totalsubscript𝔼superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉1delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptm𝓉122\displaystyle\leq\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}{\mathbb{E}_{\{\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\}}}\left[\lVert\textbf{m}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
=α2​Etotal​𝔼{g~k(𝓉−1)}​[∑k=0K−1∥g~k(𝓉−1)∥22]absentsuperscript𝛼2subscript𝐸totalsubscript𝔼superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉1delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉122\displaystyle=\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}{\mathbb{E}_{\{\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\}}}\left[\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
=α2​Etotal​∑k=0K−1𝔼g~k(𝓉−1)​[∥g~k(𝓉−1)∥22]absentsuperscript𝛼2subscript𝐸totalsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝔼superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉1delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript~g𝑘𝓉122\displaystyle=\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}{\mathbb{E}_{\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}}}\left[\lVert\tilde{\textbf{g}}_{k}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
≤α2​Etotal​(K​∥g(𝓉−1)∥22+∑k=0K−1δk+2​g(𝓉−1)T​∑k=0K−1ak(𝓉−1)⏟=0).absentsuperscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉122superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘2superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉1Tsubscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscriptsuperscripta𝓉1𝑘absent0\displaystyle\leq\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}\left(K\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}+\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}+2{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}}^{\rm T}\underbrace{\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}{\textbf{{a}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}_{k}}_{=0}\right).

Therefore, the expected improvement given in Appendix B with AAM can be re-expressed as

𝔼​[F​(w(𝓉+1))−F​(w(𝓉))]=−η​g(𝓉)T​𝔼​[v^(𝓉)]+η2​L2​𝔼​[∥v^(𝓉)∥22]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptw𝓉1𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝜂superscriptsuperscriptg𝓉T𝔼delimited-[]superscript^v𝓉superscript𝜂2𝐿2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^v𝓉22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)})-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})\right]=-\eta{{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}}^{\rm T}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\right]+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert\hat{\textbf{{v}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]~{}
≤(−η+η22​L)​∥g(𝓉)∥22+η22​L​α2​Etotal​K​∥g(𝓉−1)∥22absent𝜂superscript𝜂22𝐿superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22superscript𝜂22𝐿superscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉122\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\leq(-\eta+\frac{\eta^{2}}{2}L)\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}+\frac{\eta^{2}}{2}L\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}
+η22​L​(α2​Etotal​K+1)​1K​∑k=0K−1δk.superscript𝜂22𝐿superscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾11𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}+\frac{\eta^{2}}{2}L(\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K+1)\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}~{}.

Considering Assumption 1, we perform a telescoping sum over the iterations and calculate the expectation over the randomness in the trajectory as

F​(w(1))−F∗𝐹superscriptw1superscript𝐹\displaystyle F(\textbf{w}^{(1)})-F^{*} ≥∑𝓉=0T−1𝔼​[F​(w(𝓉))−F​(w(𝓉+1))]absentsuperscriptsubscript𝓉0𝑇1𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptw𝓉𝐹superscriptw𝓉1\displaystyle\geq\sum_{\mathscr{t}=0}^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\left[F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t})})-F(\textbf{w}^{(\mathscr{t}+1)})\right]
≥(−η+η2​L2)​𝔼​[∑𝓉=1T∥g(𝓉)∥22]absent𝜂superscript𝜂2𝐿2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉1𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22\displaystyle\geq(-\eta+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}){\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=1}^{T}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
+η22​L​α2​Etotal​K​𝔼​[∑𝓉=1T∥g(𝓉−1)∥22]superscript𝜂22𝐿superscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉1𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉122\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}+\frac{\eta^{2}}{2}L\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K{\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=1}^{T}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]
+η2​L​T2​(α2​Etotal​K+1)​1K​∑k=0K−1δk.superscript𝜂2𝐿𝑇2superscript𝛼2subscript𝐸total𝐾11𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1subscript𝛿𝑘\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}+\frac{\eta^{2}LT}{2}(\alpha^{2}E_{\rm total}K+1)\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\delta_{k}~{}. (34)

Also, we can express the expected value of the sum over the trajectory as

𝔼​[∑𝓉=1T∥g(𝓉−1)∥22]=𝔼​[∑𝓉=1T∥g(𝓉)∥22]+𝔼​[∥g(0)∥22−∥g(T)∥22].𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉1𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉122𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝓉1𝑇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝓉22𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg022superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptg𝑇22\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=1}^{T}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t}-1)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]={\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{\mathscr{t}=1}^{T}\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(\mathscr{t})}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]+{\mathbb{E}}\left[\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(0)}\rVert_{2}^{2}-\lVert{\textbf{{g}}}^{(T)}\rVert_{2}^{2}\right]~{}. (35)

Finally, by using (35) and rearranging the terms in (34), (29) is obtained. ∎
